wikipedia_page.main: John Leslie Sissons (born 30 September 1945) is an English former footballer who played for West Ham United, Sheffield Wednesday, Norwich City and Chelsea.

response: * 1975 Clyde Best, John Sissons, Derek Smethurst

link_mentions.page: West Ham United F.C. Under-23s and Academy
response: The 'Academy of Football' term was first used in the early years of Ron Greenwood's reign as West Ham manager (1961–1974).  Greenwood had inherited a young team of players from Ted Fenton and the club was noted for its reliance on home grown talent with Bobby Moore, Martin Peters, Geoff Hurst, John Lyall, Ronnie Boyce, John Sissons, Alan Sealey and Harry Redknapp all in the first team or periphery.  Further foundations had been laid with stalwart Ken Brown at the back, Malcolm Musgrove on the left wing (who was to leave in the second season), and the addition of John "Budgie" Byrne up front.
West Ham won the FA Cup Final for the first time, coming from behind to beat Preston North End 3–2.  The goals were scored by John Sissons, Geoff Hurst and Ronnie Boyce.
